body: So it looks like the tests didn't get updated. I spent a little time on it and got the scala tests updated, but still seeing some issues related to Mockito, let me try to fix those and then I will push a commit to your pr.
I finally found some time to spend on this PR, it's not completely passing all tests, but we are down to a hand full ones to fix.
For testing it locally, instead of just `make dist` try `make clean dist test`

I have done this previously and tested it.  Although it does work in Dataproc to make Toree's internal download function to 'cache JARs', The jar classes are not useable in the notebook itself.  I assume not all permutations of Spark paths (runtime, repl, etc) are updated. 

You can test this in a the kernel by simply importing a class from a JAR that was called to download with this magic.
@lresende any update on this change?

> I have done this previously and tested it. Although it does work in Dataproc to make Toree's internal download function to 'cache JARs', The jar classes are not useable in the notebook itself. I assume not all permutations of Spark paths (runtime, repl, etc) are updated.
> 
> You can test this in a the kernel by simply importing a class from a JAR that was called to download with this magic.

@kristopherkane could you tell more about "not usable" here? I tested by `AddJar` and then `import` classes from that jar in the notebook, and it works there. Also I verified in the Spark application UI, where the jar has been added to the classpath.
@ywskycn Interesting. I compiled this same change last week and did that to no avail on Dataproc 2.1. Is Dataproc also your runtime environment?

@kristopherkane yes. What I have done:

- Apply this change to tags/v0.5.0-incubating-rc5 and `make dist`
- Use the newly built `dist/toree/lib/toree-assembly-0.5.0-incubating.jar` to replace `/opt/conda/miniconda3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/toree/lib/toree-assembly-0.5.0-incubating.jar` and `/opt/conda/miniconda3/share/jupyter/kernels/apache_toree_scala/lib/toree-assembly-0.5.0-incubating.jar` in a Dataproc cluster (image 2.1-debian11 with Jupyter component enabled).
- Test %AddJar and import command in a new notebook file, and it works well there.

Those are my exact steps and toree jar locations.  

Did you by chance change any spark:spark* configuration at cluster creation?
I also should say, my comment doesn't hold this PR up.  That schema will be required regardless.

> Those are my exact steps and toree jar locations.
> 
> Did you by chance change any spark:spark* configuration at cluster creation?

no, I just follow all default configs, only specifying image version and Jupyter component.
OK, thanks!

ping @lresende, could you review this PR when you have time?

BTW, this is an awesome project, please let me know what I can do for this project :)
I'm familiar with Spark and Scala(but sorry for my poor Python skill), and am learning how to implement a Jupyter kernel using Java/Scala.

Meanwhile, I participated in two incubating Apache projects(Kyuubi is graduated and Celeborn is incubating, both are active projects), maybe I can help with some community affairs, e.g. driving new releases.
The UT stuck is irrelevant, fixed in TOREE-540 (https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/pull/205)

@pan3793 Thanks for all the enhancements, it is very welcomed. 

for this pr in specific, let's wait to merge it when the #199 gets merged... which, btw, if you want to help fix the remaining failing issues, we would welcome the help.

@lresende thanks for your reply.

I actually took a look at #199 first, and thought it composes of

- upgrade spark 3.3
- upgrade scala 2.13
- upgrade some dependencies which the current version does not support scala 2.13, for example, coursier (contains many breaking changes)

This PR could be treated as part of that. And as I commented before

> Spark 3.0 ~ 3.5 uses Scala 2.12 by default, it rarely uses a non-default Scala version in production, so I would like to upgrade the Spark first.

would it be good to upgrade Scala 2.13 at the current stage?

I updated the PR description to add @requaos(the original author of https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/pull/199) and me as the co-author, from the tech view, I lean toward breaking down the huge PR into dedicated ones, and keep using Scala 2.12 during Spark 3.x serial.

@lresende WDYT? Of course, if you think we should work on https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/pull/199, I would close this one and try to fix that.
Seems the test still has a chance to stuck, needs further investigations

> @lresende WDYT? Of course, if you think we should work on #199, I would close this one and try to fix that.

It's ok, let me test this and will review/merge based on that.

If this change is passable, then we can refocus #199 to introduce Scala 2.13, as upgrading Spark was ancillary to that effort. Let me know, because as is these commits will directly conflict with my branch for the overlap from copying my changes over instead of some other merge or cherrypick strategy. I will happily split up the efforts in my branch behind #199.

@pan3793 This effort is poised to provide Scala 2.13 notebook kernel functionality. This overcomes a direct need in the field to have a hands-on Scala 2.13-based repl, and/or Jupyter, experience. The effort here will build on up-to-date Spark version support. Please let me know what I can do to prepare this PR into the singular context of Scala 2.13 support.

@requaos thanks for sharing the background, I skimmed through the change, the most of the efforts are spent on dependencies upgrading, and unfortunately, some of them introduce breaking changes so a lot of code need to be adjusted. e.g. Spark, scalatest, mockito, coursier. It is worth upgrading them in independent PRs.

And I believe some of the dependencies upgradings are not required, e.g. sbt, akka. Especially, akka changed the license from Apache V2 to BSL v1.1 in 2.7, the latter is not allowed by Apache projects.

https://www.thestack.technology/akka-license-change-lightbend-opensource/
https://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x

@requaos May I ask a little more about the requirements of Scala 2.13?

This is a Spark ecosystem project, most dependencies are intended to align with Spark, as I mentioned above

> Spark 3.0 ~ 3.5 uses Scala 2.12 by default, it rarely uses a non-default Scala version in production

So I suppose changing it to Scala 2.13 and dropping 2.12 looks aggressive. It makes more sense if we can support both Scala 2.12 and 2.13 and use 2.12 in default, but this means introducing some refactoring of the building system.

> ... as is these commits will directly conflict with my branch for the overlap from copying my changes over instead of some other merge or cherrypick strategy.

@requaos Yes, this change starts from scratch, because I can not achieve it by cherry-picking in a clean way. I respect your effort in #199 so I add you as co-author of this PR. If necessary, I can help with git rebase and conflict resolution, which requires write permission of your forked repo(the committer of this project is granted write permission on PR branch automatically, for other contributors like me, explicitly granting is required).

@pan3793 Yes, this is a larger effort than initially planned and I have not been as considerate of license for dependency updates. Planning forward to support both Scala 2.12 and 2.13, with a default preference for 2.12, will be most optimal.
I can accommodate upstream changes in my fork to assist in this effort. As you see fit to divide this labor, I will gladly reduce the scope of my PR to reflect an incremental task to work more gradually towards our shared goal.

@requaos Thanks, as part of this PR, I think you can upgrade coursier to the latest 2.x version in a separate PR first, to gain support for both Scala 2.12 and 2.13.

I would like to take a look at scalatest/mockito stuff after #201 gets merged.
kindly ping @lresende and @kevin-bates, would you mind taking a look when you have time?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/pull/207 is opened to address "status" issue.
I see a lot of updates adding status "ok"... how about error conditions when something fail?

@lresende I think the code won't reach there if something fails before it. Note that, only a few kind simple reply messages did not implement the status, for message like `ExecuteReply` which already has status field with properly handled.
@lresende FYI, I changed the code to use `type XyzReplyOk = XyzReply` to keep consistent with the current code, no functionality changes.
BTW, I see there are other ignored test cases, some of them involve complex backgrounds, I would like to fix them one by one gradually.
@lresende @kevin-bates would you mind taking another look? IMO this does not change the state of error handling, should be safe.
@lresende would you mind taking a look at this PR? it is based on your previous in-progress work.

Seems to help but still has a chance to hang, open TOREE-548 to address it in another approach.

Note: this PR does not conflict with TOREE-548, the CI shows it reduces the hang rate compared to the master branch, the reviewer could decide to merge it or ignore it.

@pan3793 I believe this is mostly done in #199, and I was wondering what would be best here. Contribute things in pieces because #199 updates scala do 2.13? Or should we continue adding to that PR to fix the remaining few test issues and merge #199 pr?

@lresende this PR is ready to go(review and merge) on my side.

> I was wondering what would be best here.

In short words, I intend to make each PR focus on one goal, especially, the large goal should be broken down into small/middle ones, which are easy to implement and review.

For #199, technically, I think it is still far from the goal, because

1. I and @requaos reached a consensus that we should not drop Scala 2.12 in Spark 3.x periods, as I explained before, Spark 3.x uses  Scala 2.12 in default, it rarely uses the non-default Scala version in production.
   >  (from @requaos) Planning forward to support both Scala 2.12 and 2.13, with a default preference for 2.12, will be most optimal.

   #199's approach totally breaks the Scala 2.12 support.

2. coursier upgrading involves some breaking changes, #199 silently changed the logging behavior(no test coverage). It is also worth accomplishing in an independent PR.

3. #199 contains many irrelevant changes, e.g. it upgraded Java 8 to 11, and it's hard to thoroughly review with so many lines of change.

As @requaos said, I think he also agrees to break it down.

> ... this is a larger effort than initially planned ...

> Please let me know what I can do to prepare this PR into the singular context of Scala 2.13 support.

> I can accommodate upstream changes in my fork to assist in this effort. As you see fit to divide this labor, I will gladly reduce the scope of my PR to reflect an incremental task to work more gradually towards our shared goal.

@lresende That's my opinion, my goal is to accomplish the upgrading quickly, keep code quality, and make the code change history clear. Please let me know if you have any other thoughts :)
Nice, the CI of recent commits on the master branch is green now :)

The test failure is irrelevant, it's another known flaky test, will investigate independently.

```
[info]   - should send a status idle message after the reply and result *** FAILED *** (15 seconds, 40 milliseconds)
[info]     0 did not equal 2 (ExecuteRequestHandlerSpec.scala:193)
[info]     org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException:
[info]     at org.scalatest.matchers.MatchersHelper$.indicateFailure(MatchersHelper.scala:397)
[info]     at org.scalatest.matchers.should.Matchers$ShouldMethodHelperClass.shouldMatcher(Matchers.scala:7299)
[info]     at org.scalatest.matchers.should.Matchers$AnyShouldWrapper.should(Matchers.scala:7362)
[info]     at org.apache.toree.kernel.protocol.v5.handler.ExecuteRequestHandlerSpec.$anonfun$new$6(ExecuteRequestHandlerSpec.scala:193)
```
Have you tested this with real job notebooks on latest jupyterlab 3.x and no side effects?
@lresende I'm really sorry about that, will do such testing for other PRs in the future.

Hello, it seems I have the same issue as you @kristopherkane even with the local `file` prefix. I am using Dataproc 2.1, by defaut I have one driver and two executors and the yarn deploy mode is `client`. Seing the jar load messages duplicated twice, I am wondering if the classes are being loaded on the executors but not on the driver? When using the Https url from[ this tutorial](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/46347728beb9ca280c05a99add131e9bcdfbaa8c/etc/examples/notebooks/magic-tutorial.ipynb), it worked. Have you an idea on the reasons? how can I debug this?

@almaaouiwassim sorry, I did not.  I've kind-of given up on Toree since we will also need kernel time Spark configuration changes and the level of effort to add those is too high, in addition to the driver not getting the AddJar classpath.
Could you clarify your additional requirements?
@lresende The ability to set Spark configuration from the kernel itself and before the SparkSession is created.

Hey guys, I am back with few steps to reproduce the issue. The `AddJar` seems to work with some jars but no all of them, I couldn't get what makes my jar not well loaded by the kernel. Here are the steps to reproduce the issue - create a 2.1.21-debian11 dataproc cluster (probably the jar won't work with other env, but this is the one I am testing with) - download the jar to the local filesystem using terminal on the notebook ```gsutil cp gs://untienots_public/myproject-assembly.jar .``` - load the jar in the notebook then do an import You can check the screenshots to see the results and to see that my jar actually contains the class that couldn't be imported The same jar is working well in dataproc jobs and spylon (another scala spark kernel), I can share the jar's code source if it can help.
@almaaouiwassim have you checked the Spark UI whether the jar was added?
@ywskycn yes it has been added to the spark configuration

@lresende I opened #218 based on this PR (I have to open a new PR because I don't have permission to commit on the original PR branch), which is a rough and dirty fix of #199, it passed building and testing on both Scala 2.12 and 2.13. I would like to continue the work after this PR get in.
@lresende thanks!
@lresende thanks!
@lresende do you have further concerns about shipping this patch?
@ywskycn did you succeed to reproduce the issue please?
Seems the master branch works well without this change.
Same result in Jupyter NbClassic
Kindly ping @lresende @kevin-bates
@pan3793 thank you for the info! We are currently using Jupyter Notebook (classic) v6.4. Do you know which commit fixed the problem? I did some search but couldn't figure it out.
This PR only touches the test code, since all tests passed and no further objections, I'm going to merge it to unblock Scala 2.13 upgrading tasks.
@functicons maybe this one https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/pull/6466
CI reports failures, investigating
@lresende would you mind taking a look?
So, #194 updated Guava, and why now, when we downgrade to the same previous version, do we need some new workarounds? If Spark uses this, can't we import the additional files from Spark?

> when we downgrade to the same previous version, do we need some new workarounds?

Yes, I explained in the PR description. "As a workaround, this PR fork a `ClassPath` from Guava v32.1.2 to make it happy with Java 11."

> If Spark uses this, can't we import the additional files from Spark?

In short, Spark 3.x **must** use Guava 14.0.1. The restriction comes from the transitive deps of Spark, including Hive and Hadoop, see details in discussions in SPARK-44811 SPARK-36676. Since Guava 14's `ClassPath`(used by Toree) is not compatible with Java 11, we should fork `ClassPath` from a higher version of Guava instead.

I have been able to reproduce the same issue. It seems the jar in the example @ywskycn suggested works fine with AddJars but one created locally using sbt does not load even though it gets downloaded into the local Toree cache from GCS. No errors/warnings show up either on screen or in the logs.
Can not reproduce the issue with the latest master [commit](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/commit/937c1260bf7973ef20b0052989398ac9e789d160)
@lresende, I found this issue during debug phase, would you please take a look?

@pan3793 can you please try with this jar `gs://untienots_public/myproject-assembly.jar` doing a 
- `gstuil cp` 
- then, loading it from local filesystem.
- then, `import com.untienots.MyObject`

I suspect it's linked to how the jar is actually built. If so I can provide my` build.sbt `file

Hello guys, sorry for the late response, I had time recently to try to understand what exactly doesn't work with Apache Toree. It seems that any jar with a class on the root classpath of the jar (not under a package) is not well added to the kernel using AddJar. 

I put a sample project to reproduce it in https://github.com/almaaouiwassim/my_project. just run `sbt assembly` to generate the jar. 

I have also put the jar on GCS https://storage.cloud.google.com/untienots_public/my_project.jar?authuser=0

The download and adding of the jar doesn't display any error, but when you `import MyObject` its not recognised.

Please tell me if you need further information. 

FI, even if you don't put classes at the root classpath, some dependencies can still do it and break your jar, in our case it was `spark-xml` who has a class `module-info.class` at the root. I guess many dependencies would do the same.
Thank you, let me do some testing and let you know, otherwise code changes lgtm
@pjfanning I finally had time to test this in some of my workloads and it seem to be ok, could you please try to re-trigger the pr ci/cd to get a green test build
@lresende the tests have passed on most recent run
@pan3793 what is the status of this pr?

@lresende I remember the `coursier` log API changed significantly, and we need to adapt the new API to recover the log display, let me find time these weeks to fix it and finish the scala 2.13 support.
@lresende I have reverted the debatable change, can we consider getting the rest change in?
@lresende I rebased it on the latest master and fixed the conflict, please take a look when you have time.

Thank you for the updates @pan3793 I did not do much testing, but updated my env to spark 3.4.3 + scala 13 and at least it connects and establishes a spark session... will try to spend more time on validation during the week.
@lresende I think this is the last major change to prepare support Scala 2.13, please take a look when you have time.
@lresende this PR is ready to review now.
